awd_titl_txt: SG: Environmental variation and optimal plant life history strategies of perennial plants
awd_abstract_narration:
How and when a species grows and reproduces is called its life history strategy. The performance of a plant's life history strategy depends on temperature, rainfall and soil nutrients. These environmental conditions vary around the world and from year to year. Over a long period of time, the life history strategy of a species adapts to the ranges of temperature, rainfall and other environmental conditions at a location. A plant adapted to do well in a desert may not be well adapted to live in a rain forest, and vice versa. When environmental conditions in a particular location change, a species' life history strategy may no longer be adapted to the new conditions, and its population growth rate may suffer. A plant species may be able to evolve a new strategy that works better in the changed environment, but the rate of adaptation may not keep pace with rapid environmental change. In that case local populations will shrink, increasing the risk of the species' extinction. Society needs to predict which plants are most at risk from changed environments to efficiently allocate scarce resources to species conservation. This study uses mathematical models to predict the best life history strategy for plant species living different environments, and to quantify how poorly adapted a species is to a change in the environment. Testing predictions of the effects of rapid environmental change on plant life history is difficult without measuring plant growth and reproduction in many years with a wide range of environmental conditions. Such long-term data sets are extremely rare, but in this study researchers will make use of a 30 year-long data set on the growth and reproduction of the plant species bitterroot milkvetch (Astragalus scaphoides), to test the predictions generated by their models. This research combines plant ecology and mathematical modeling, and will provide training for graduate and undergraduate students in both disciplines. 

The researchers will construct general models predicting life history strategies that maximize fitness measured as life time reproduction or population growth rate. Assuming natural selection selects for genotypes that maximize fitness, optimization models predict optimal life history strategies for various environmental conditions. Specifically, the models will answer the following questions: (1) What resource allocation strategy (growth, storage, reproduction) and dormancy frequency optimizes the fitness of perennial plants under different environmental conditions (nutrient availability, temperature, precipitation)? (2) What are the fitness consequences of rapidly changing environmental conditions? Further, the researchers will use a long term data set on performance of a perennial plant, A. scaphoides, to test the model predictions by asking: (3) Is the magnitude of observed variation in temperature and precipitation sufficient to negatively affect plant fitness?

por.por_cntn:
Global climate change has severely damaged both terrestrial and marine ecosystems, and in many cases, they are pushed beyond their ability to adapt. Key to predicting and mitigating the effect of climate change are long-term monitoring projects because we need to measure the response of natural populations to weather conditions that include different combinations of high and low temperature, and high and low rainfall. Unfortunately, such long-term monitoring studies are rare. As an alternative, researchers have manipulated temperature and rainfall conditions experimentally but unfortunately this approach does not always provide reliable estimates of the impact of climate change on plant and animal populations. This research continued the monitoring project on the wildflower Astragalus scaphoides that started in 1988 and added four more years to the data set. This species is a long-lived wildflower growing exclusively in the high-elevation sagebrush steppes in southwestern Montana and east-central Idaho.

At the beginning of the project the researchers explored if weather variables influence plant vital rates including survival, growth, reproduction, using a subset of the data (1988-2014). The analysis showed that the flowering probability of plants, recruitment (establishment of new plants), and survival are all influenced by weather variables. Additionally, for most vital rates they also detected delayed effects which means that this year's weather influences the vital rates of plants in the following year. The reason for the delayed effects can be explained by the resource dynamics of plants. For instance, since A. scaphoides grows in a resource scarce environment plants cannot accumulate the amount of resources necessary for flowering. So, depending on the weather, plants can only flower every other year or every three years. Accordingly, the researchers show that the plant's population growth rate in any given years is highest if a dry year is followed by a wet year because when it is dry plants do not flower but they still accumulate some resources; if then the following year is wet, plants increase their resource pool to a level that is sufficient to produce flowers, fruits, and seeds. However, the analysis did not show any effect of weather variables on the likelihood of plants to enter prolonged dormancy, which is a process where plants stay under ground for one or growing seasons. However, when using the entire data set (1988-2020) the analysis revealed that the probability of plants entering dormancy increased if the temperature was high over the last 20 months and plants should come out of dormancy and sprout if a dry year is followed by a wet winter and spring. The reason for why the earlier analysis did not detect an effect of temperature on prolonged dormancy is because in any given year only a small proportion of plants stays dormant  (<15%), and detecting a weather signal for rare events requres very long data sets.
